questions.text: An obese man was posted for bariatric surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Desflurane is the inhalational anesthetic agent of choice for this patient.

In obese individuals, the increased fat stores increase the volume of distribution for lipid-soluble drugs when compared to a lean individual of the same body weight. This increases the peripheral distribution of the lipid-soluble agents thus resulting in increased recovery time. There is an increase in the cardiac output in obese individuals that increases the early distribution of the drugs. Hence fat-soluble drugs should be administered based on the total body weight. Water-soluble agents like neuromuscular blockers have a smaller peripheral distribution that is minimally increased by body fat. Therefore, water-soluble agents are dosed based on the ideal body weight.

Among the commonly used inhalational anesthetics, desflurane is the least fat-soluble which leads to a faster recovery. Desflurane is also minimally metabolized by the liver, thereby reducing hepatotoxicity. 

Inhalational agent Blood-gas partition coefficient
Halothane 2.5
Isoflurane 1.4
Sevoflurane 0.65
Desflurane 0.45

Blood-gas partition co-efficient determines the solubility of the anesthetic agent in the blood. The higher the blood-gas partition coefficient, the higher will be the solubility of the anesthetic agent. This leads to its greater uptake by pulmonary circulation. The higher the uptake of the anesthetic agent, the higher the difference between the inspired and alveolar concentrations, which leads to a slower rate of induction and recovery. Desflurane has a very low blood:gas partition coefficient (0.42). Thus, the alveolar and blood concentrations rapidly rise to the level of inspired concentration, providing rapid induction of anesthesia and rapid recovery.

Other options:

Option A- Halothane is a high fat-soluble agent and can result in halothane hepatitis due to increased metabolism in obese individuals. Hence it is avoided.

Option C- Sevoflurane has a relatively higher fat solubility compared to desflurane.

Option D- Isoflurane has a higher fat-gas partition co-efficient resulting in increased recovery time from anesthesia.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice: 

Indication Anesthetic gas
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

 

Feature Drug
Most potent       Methoxyflurane > Halothane 
Least potent      Nitrous oxide > Desflurane 
Most epileptogenic   Enflurane
Most nephrotoxic Methoxyflurane 
Most hepatotoxic Halothane

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male patient is brought by his daughter after claiming to have seen a snake on multiple occasions even though one was not present. He has had difficulty with performing daily activities for the past 8 months. Examination reveals bradykinesia and rigidity. No personality changes were observed. MMSE score is 20 with relative sparing of memory. What is the most likely diagnosis?

MMSE - mini-mental state examination
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of Lewy-body dementia.

Fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and motor symptoms of Parkinson's like bradykinesia and rigidity are the core features that help in the diagnosis of this disease. Characteristically, dementia in this condition develops very early and usually within 1 year of the onset of motor symptoms. Memory is usually spared in this condition.  MMSE score of less than 24 out of 30 indicates impaired cognitive function. 

Dementia with Lewy bodies is a progressive neurodegenerative associated with dementia, psychosis, and features of Parkinsonism. It is characterized by the protein deposition of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra, limbic system, and cerebral cortex, comprising α-synuclein and ubiquitin. It is the third most common type of dementia after Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia.

The clinical features of dementia with Lewy bodies are characterized by visual hallucinations, features of Parkinsonism, neuroleptic sensitivity, REM (rapid eye movement) sleep disorder, and excessive daytime sleepiness. They can also present with delirium and orthostatic hypotension. Memory is usually preserved in patients with Lewy body dementia. If a typical antipsychotic is prescribed for hallucinations and mild cognitive deficits, it can result in profound extrapyramidal adverse effects due to the sensitivity to neuroleptic agents. The features of Parkinsonism would include bradykinesia, resting tremor, and cog-wheel rigidity.

Dementia or neuropsychiatric conditions emerge concurrently with parkinsonism features in dementia with Lewy bodies whereas Parkinson's disease dementia occurs in long-standing cases of Parkinson's disease. Recently it has been decided that if dementia or any cognitive disability occurs after 12 months of Parkinson's disease, then the disorder is most likely Parkinson's disease dementia.

The pharmacotherapy would include cholinesterase inhibitors like rivastigmine, galantamine, and donepezil to treat the cognitive impairments. Other medications include antidepressants, and low-potency atypical antipsychotics to treat depression and hallucinations respectively.

Other options:

Option A- No history of personality changes rules out frontotemporal dementia.

Option B- Alzheimer's disease is ruled out as the memory is intact in the patient.

Option C- Parkinson's disease dementia is dementia occurring in long-standing cases of Parkinson's disease. It causes impairment of memory, attention, visual perception, hallucinations, and depression. It is diagnosed along with a prior diagnosis of Parkinson's disease and the onset of dementia occurring after 12 months of motor dysfunction of Parkinson's disease.

Note - Hallucinations in Parkinson's disease dementia occur late in Parkinson's disease and is seen after medication use.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

Related Pearl: Synucleinopathies and tauopathies

Synucleinopathies:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
  • REM behavioral disorder
  • Pure autonomic failure 
Tauopathies:
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Down syndrome
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Corticobasal degeneration
  • Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia
  • Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica
  • Postencephalitic parkinsonism
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration
  • Niemann Pick disease type C
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

Related Pearl: Parkinson plus syndrome

Condition Lesion
MSA/Shy dragger syndrome

Parkinson disease +

 Dysautonomia 
MSAc Cerebellar symptoms
MSAp Pyramidal symptoms 
Progressive supranuclear palsy Supranuclear palsy
Lewy body dementia Early dementia 

MSA - Multi System Atrophy

Parkinson plus syndrome

  • Faster progress of disease
  • Poor response to levodopa
  • Poor prognosis
  • Increased mortality

questions.text: Anaplerosis is the process of refilling the catalytic intermediates of the citric acid cycle that carry acetyl CoA as it gets oxidized. All of the following are anaplerotic reactions, except _____.

choices.text: Conversion of succinyl CoA to heme
Conversion of propionyl CoA to succinyl CoA

questions.solution:
Conversion of succinyl CoA to heme is not an anaplerotic reaction. It is an example of a cataplerotic reaction.

The anaplerotic process is the replenishment of the intermediates of the citric acid (Krebs) cycle to replace the catalytic processes and to ensure the continuation of the cycle.

The most important anaplerotic reaction is the carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which is catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. This reaction is important to maintain an adequate concentration of oxaloacetate for the condensation reaction with acetyl-CoA. On accumulation, acetyl-CoA acts as an allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase and an inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase, thereby providing an adequate supply of oxaloacetate.

Other anaplerotic reactions:

  • Glutamate and glutamine to α-ketoglutarate, a reaction catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase and glutaminase, respectively
  • Compounds that produce propionyl CoA can be then carboxylated and isomerized to succinyl CoA.
  • Transamination of aspartate to form oxaloacetate.
  • Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate.

The cataplerotic process is the metabolism of the citric acid cycle intermediates that leave the cycle and participate in the biosynthesis of other compounds. These processes are required to redirect citrate toward fatty acid synthesis; succinyl CoA to heme synthesis, malate to gluconeogenesis; and α-ketoglutarate to amino acid synthesis, purine synthesis, and neurotransmitter synthesis.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: On examination of a 26-year-old man, tachycardia was observed during inspiration. The doctor told him that it is respiratory sinus arrhythmia. Which of the following mechanism explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The above mechanism is explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

Tachycardia, in response to increased venous return, is suggestive of Bainbridge reflex. During inspiration, there is an increased venous return due to reduced intrathoracic pressure. This leads to right atrial distension. The stretch receptors of the atria transmit the afferent signals via the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. The efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to result in tachycardia and increase the strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option B: Bezold–Jarisch reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing. It is seen in cases of myocardial ischemia and reperfusion due to the increased synthesis of oxygen free radicals. 

Option C: Cushing reflex: When there is increased intracranial pressure, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. 

Option D: J reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) due to hyperinflation of the lung causes reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia and hypotension.

questions.text: The life cycle of which of the following is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus.

Nipah virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae, genus Henipavirus. It is a zoonotic virus that shows both animal-to-human (bats, pigs) and human-to-human transmission. The natural hosts are fruit bats of the Pteropodidae family.

The clinical manifestations include asymptomatic subclinical infection, acute respiratory infection, and fatal encephalitis. There is no treatment or vaccine available for either people or animals. The primary treatment for humans is supportive care.

Nipah virus is on the WHO list of Blueprint priority diseases.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presented with painful, bleeding genital ulcers. On examination, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Scraping from the ulcer base was taken and the microscopic appearance of the Gram-stained smear is shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The image shows the' school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi. This appearance is seen when the bacilli are arranged in small groups, whorls or in chains. The given case scenario is suggestive of chancroid.

Chancroid is characterized by non-indurated, tender, irregular ulcers that may bleed on touch. The neighbouring lymph nodes are enlarged, painful, and tender. 

Other options:

Option B - Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, characterised by chancre - a single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border, with painless lymphadenopathy. Persistent or multiple chancres may be seen in HIV-infected or other immunodeficient patients.

Options C and D - Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2 and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum, characterised by shallow, painless ulcers that progress to painful lymphadenopathy.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presented with a fever and malaise. On examination, petechiae, a tender, pink nodule on her finger, and a cardiac murmur were appreciated. A probable diagnosis of bacterial endocarditis was made and the blood culture was positive for enterococci. Which of the following is true about enterococcus?

PYR: Pyrrolidinyl-beta-naphtylamide
questions.solution:
Enterococcus is non-hemolytic on blood agar.

Enterococcus belongs to the streptococcaceae family and belongs to the Lancefield D group. Enterococcus includes organisms like E.fecalis, E.faecium, and E.durans. They are gram-positive oval cocci that are paired and are arranged at an angle to each other. 

Enterococcus species are generally non-hemolytic, although alpha or beta hemolysis is shown by some of the strains. They show growth in 6.5% sodium chloride, 40% bile, at a pH of 9.6, and in 0.1% methylene blue milk. It can cause urinary tract and biliary tract infections, endocarditis, and suppurative infections like an intra-abdominal abscess.

Other important characteristics of enterococcus are:

  • They are relatively heat-resistant
  • They are PYR (pyrrolidinyl-beta-naphtylamide) test positive 
  • Tiny magenta pink colonies are formed on MacConkey medium
  • They ferment mannitol, sorbitol, sucrose and esculin
  • They produce black colonies on tellurite blood agar

Treatment: Vancomycin is the drug of choice for drug-resistant enterococcal infections.

Other options:

Option A- Novobiocin sensitivity is seen in Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Option B- PYR test negative is seen in Streptococcus anginosus.

Option C- Optochin sensitivity is associated with Streptococcus pneumonia while Viridans streptococci are optochin-resistant.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient in her 16th week of gestation came for prenatal karyotyping since her first child is suffering from Down's syndrome. Which among the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: Limb reduction defect is a known complication

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is amniocentesis. Limb reduction defect is not a known complication of amniocentesis, it is a complication of chorionic villous sampling. 

Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle. The needle is directed perpendicularly into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure. Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis. 

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

15-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks (associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

Indications

Congenital infections

Fetal genetic disorders

Alloimmunization

Assessment of lung maturity
Complications

Fetal loss

Amniotic fluid leakage

Transvaginal spotting

 

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with throat pain, fever, and pain with swallowing. When he attempts to speak his voice is muffled. The patient tilts his head to his right side. Physical examination shows findings as seen in the image.  Contrast-enhanced CT and needle aspiration reveal the diagnosis. Which of the following is not a complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
Periodontal abscess is not an expected complication in this disease. The above clinical features and the above image are suggestive of Quinsy or peritonsillar abscess.

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

The clinical features are sore throat, odynophagia, muffled voice (hot potato voice), foul breath, dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever. 

Physical examination reveals congestion of tonsils, pillars, and soft palate, swollen and edematous uvula pushed to the other side, mucopus over tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, and torticollis. This tonsillar swelling can be differentiated from other tonsillar swellings by yellowish spots of purulent material at the opening of crypts (acute follicular tonsillitis), presence of membrane over the tonsils (acute membranous tonsillitis, diphtheria, infectious mononucleosis, vincent angina), or extensive swelling and congestion of the tonsils that they may meet in the midline (acute parenchymatous tonsillitis)

Diagnosis is through CECT/MRI or aspiration of fluid in the abscess.

Management: Antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 4-6 weeks later. Some surgeons prefer surgery during active disease known as a hot tonsillectomy, but this has the risk of rupture and bleeding.

Complications:

  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Retropharyngeal abscess
  • Airway obstruction
  • Septicemia
  • Pneumonitis
  • Jugular vein thrombosis
  • Spontaneous hemorrhage from carotid artery or jugular vein

 

 

Related Pearl: Compartments of the parapharyngeal space

  Prestyloid Poststyloid
Relation to styloid Anterior Posterior
Relations

Medially: Tonsillar fossa

Laterally: Medial pterygoid muscle

Medially: Posterior part of the lateral pharyngeal wall

Laterally: Parotid gland
Contents Medial pterygoid muscle

Carotid artery

Jugular vein, IXth, Xth, XIth, XIIth cranial nerves

Sympathetic trunk
Presentation

Prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa,

Spasm of medial pterygoid muscle leading to trismus

The pharynx bulging behind the posterior pillar

Injury to of CN IX, X, XI, and XII leading to vocal cord paralysis

Sympathetic chain injury leading to Horner’s syndrome

Swelling of the parotid region

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient with dyspepsia, weight loss, and melena is being evaluated with a barium upper gastrointestinal study. An outpouching with a smooth, deep ulcer crater is seen along the lesser gastric curvature and is diagnosed to be a benign gastric ulcer. Which of the following radiological feature is suggestive of a benign gastric ulcer?
questions.solution:
The radiological feature that is suggestive of a benign gastric ulcer is Hampton's line.

Hampton’s line is usually a 1 mm thin, radiolucent line seen at the neck of the ulcer that represents a rim of undermined mucosa, seen in barium studies. Hampton’s line is a feature of benign gastric ulcers.

Other features of a benign ulcer include-

  • Location on the lesser curvature
  • Extends beyond the gastric wall
  • Smooth ulcer mound - representative of edema
  • Smooth folds reaching up to the edge of the ulcer
  • Heals completely

Other options:

Option A- Hampton's hump is a radiologic sign associated with pulmonary embolism. It consists of a shallow wedge-shaped opacity in the periphery of the lung with its base against the pleural surface.

Option C- Carman meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers and describes the lenticular shape of barium in the shallow/flat malignant ulcer, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen (benign ulcers are concave towards the lumen). Other features of malignant ulcers include irregular ulcer base, nodular mound, and thickened, interrupted, and fused folds around the ulcer.

Option D- Ram’s horn sign is seen in Crohn’s disease of the stomach leading to deformity of the antrum with a tubular shape, conical narrowing, and limited distensibility of the stomach, resembling the shape of a horn.

questions.text: Identify the muscle attached at the marked location in this posterior surface of the femur.
questions.solution:
The marked structure in this posterior surface of the femur is the intertrochanteric crest. The muscle attached at this location is the quadratus femoris. 

Quadratus femoris muscle originates from the upper part of the external aspect of the ischial tuberosity and is inserted on a small tubercle above the middle of the intertrochanteric crest of the femur. It mainly causes lateral rotation at the hip joint. It is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris.

 

Below is the image showing posterior hip muscles:

 

Other options:

Option A) Obturator externus originates from the obturator membrane and from the adjacent pubic and ischial rami. It is inserted into the trochanteric fossa of the femur. It assists in lateral rotation at the hip joint. It is innervated by the posterior branch of the obturator nerve

Option C) Gluteus medius originates from the outer surface of the ilium between the anterior and posterior gluteal lines and from the strong fascia superficial to its upper part. It is inserted into the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. It acts with the gluteus minimus to cause abduction and medial rotation at the hip joint. It is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

Option D) Gluteus minimus originates from the outer surface of the ilium between the anterior and inferior gluteal lines and from the margin of the greater sciatic notch. It is inserted into the anterolateral ridge of the greater trochanter and also contributes to the capsule of the hip joint. Its main actions are abduction and medial rotation at the hip joint. It is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur:

Related Pearl: Muscles causing the movements at Hip joint

Biceps femoris

Semitendinosus

Semimembranosus (hamstrings)

 
Abduction

Gluteus minimus

Gluteus maximus (upper muscle fibres)

Assisted by tensor fascia lata, piriformis and sartorius.
Adduction

Adductor longus

Adductor brevis

Adductor magnus

Gracilis 
Medial rotation

Gluteus medius

Gluteus minimus

Tensor Fascia Lata

Adductor muscles.
Lateral rotation

Superior and inferior gemelli

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who is a chronic opioid addict for 5 years comes to the hospital for delivery. She gives a history of opioid abuse throughout the pregnancy. A day after being born, the baby develops irritability, hypertonia, seizures, and poor sucking reflex. The random blood sugar of the baby is normal. On examination, there is no icterus.  Which of the following drugs should be administered to the baby to counter the symptoms?
questions.solution:
Methadone should be administered to the baby to counter the symptoms. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal abstinence syndrome of opioids.

Neonatal abstinence syndrome is a drug-withdrawal syndrome most commonly associated with in-utero exposure to maternal opioids. It is characterized by irritability, hypertonia, autonomic instability, seizures, and poor sucking reflex.

Methadone is a long-acting opioid agonist with pharmacological properties similar to morphine. It is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. It has been used as a replacement agent in heroin addiction. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. Because of its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in mild but protracted withdrawal symptoms.

Methadone and other opioids like morphine can be given in neonatal abstinence syndrome.

Other options: 

Option A- Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that is used in the treatment of opioid overdose. It should be avoided in opioid-dependent individuals and opioid-dependent mothers as it might lead to withdrawal syndrome.

Option C- Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that is used in the treatment of opioid overdose, alcohol dependence, and in combination with bupropion in obesity.

Option D- Nalmefene is an opioid receptor antagonist used in the treatment of opioid overdose. It has also been approved to reduce heavy alcohol consumption.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features
Alcohol
Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old photographer presented with confusion, delirium, and corrosion near the mouth. He was found with an empty bottle containing hydrocyanic acid. He is tachycardic and hypotensive. Resuscitative measures are unsuccessful, and his body is sent for postmortem analysis. What would be the color of post-mortem hypostasis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of hydrocyanic acid (HCN) poisoning, and the colour of postmortem hypostasis in case of HCN poisoning is brick red. 

HCN is a toxic chemical acid found in bitter almonds, peaches, apples, cherries, etc. It has the smell of bitter almonds. It is usually present in its glycoside form, amygdalin, along with certain co-enzymes like emulsion complex, these co-enzymes hydrolyze amygdalin to release HCN. HCN is a common chemical used in leather tanning, electroplating, metal extractions, and photographic fixing. 

Mechanism of action: It is a protoplasmic poison releasing cyanide ions, which inhibit complex IV of cellular respiratory enzyme systems. It leads to histotoxic anoxia.

Postmortem findings: 

  • External: The smell of bitter almonds, brick red postmortem hypostasis. Rigor mortis appears early, and jaws are firmly closed.
  • Internal: In suspected cyanide poisoning cases, the cranial cavity should be opened first to perceive the bitter almond smell that is marked in brain tissue. Diffuse cerebral oedema such that white and gray matter cannot be differentiated, haemorrhages in the lungs.

Toxicological analysis: Preserve lungs to demonstrate the gas in a nylon bag. The spleen is the best specimen to demonstrate cyanide poisoning.

Laboratory diagnosis includes a classical triad of

  1. Narrow arterio-venous oxygen difference,
  2. Anion-gap metabolic acidosis, and
  3. Elevated lactate concentration.

HCN may be identified by gas chromatography or spectrophotometry.

Lee-Jones Test: This test indicates the presence of cyanide. The test can be positive for salicylates, too.

Treatment: Shift the patient to a room with fresh air and remove his clothes. Establish proper airway, breathing, and circulation. Inhalational amyl nitrate is administered, and 100% oxygen therapy is also given. Wash skin and eyes with large amounts of water to remove any contact poison, if any. A slow infusion of 3% sodium nitrate solution, followed by a slow infusion of 25% sodium thiosulfate solution, is given.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

Poisoning/Condition Postmortem staining

Carbon monoxide   

Cherry red
Cyanides     

Brick red/dark pink

Potassium chlorate

 Chocolate brown 
Phosphorous  Dark brown 
Nitrites   

Red-brown

Hydrogen sulphide

Bluish-green
Opium  Greyish/black
Asphyxia Dark purple
Hypothermia Bright pink
Septic abortion (Cl. Perfringens infection) Pale bronze

Related Pearl: Characteristic Odor of Toxins

Odor

Toxins

Garlic odor

 

Arsenic, phosphorous, malathion, thallium carbonate

Odorless

Thallium sulfate (most common), thallium oxide

Garlic odor or rotten fish

Zinc phosphide

Odor of burnt rope

Cannabis

Phenolic odor

Carbolic acid
Smell of bitter almonds Cyanide
Fruity odor Ethyl alcohol
Rotten egg Hydrogen sulphide
Smell of kerosene Organophosphorous

Related Pearl: Specific antidotes for poisoning

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy who is a known case of protein C deficiency presents with a painful limp on the right side. His parents give a history of limping after he comes home after playing, 1 week back. On examination,  he is afebrile. The boy whines with pain during passive movement of the hip. The range of motion is restricted in the abduction and internal rotation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Perthes disease.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. The incidence is more in boys than girls. It is usually unilateral disease but can occur bilaterally in 10% of the cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

The disease is characterized by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head due to which the bone goes for osteonecrosis and stops growing. The lateral epiphyseal artery, a branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include pain and limping. Pain aggravates on doing any activity and relieves by rest. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip and abduction with internal rotation movement is limited.

Xray findings depend on the stages 

  • Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus
  • Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis
  • Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase
  • Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

The below radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodelling in Perthes disease.

Treatment:

Children under 6 years - symptomatic treatment including activity modification, reduction in weight-bearing, abduction bracing, bisphosphonates

Children aged 6-8 years - Operative management with proximal femoral varus osteotomy

For children aged 9 and above - operative management with pelvic osteotomy

Other options:

Option A- Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option B- Slipped capital femoral epiphysis occurs most likely in the age group of 10-15 years with an associated endocrinal disorder.

Option D- Septic arthritis can be ruled as the boy is afebrile in the given scenario. It presents as severe tenderness and all movements are abolished due to muscle spasm.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent blood in stools and altered bowel habits for the past 3 months. After a detailed evaluation, she is diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma which is located at the distal third of the rectum and anal sphincters. There is no nodal or distant metastasis. What is the preferred management for this patient?

(APR-Abdominoperineal resection)
questions.solution:
Abdominoperineal resection with permanent colostomy is preferred for this patient. 

Abdominoperineal resection is the complete excision of the entire rectum, anal canal, and anus with the construction of a permanent colostomy from the descending or sigmoid colon.

Abdominoperineal resection is recommended for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas who satisfy the following conditions:

  • The tumor is located within 5cm of the anal verge.
  • Obtaining a negative distal margin (with a clearance of 5 cm proximally and 2 cm distally) is not feasible.
  • There is involvement or invasion of nearby structures, such as the external sphincter.

The most common immediate complication of APR is an intraabdominal or pelvic abscess. During pelvic dissection, there are many sites at which autonomic nerves that affect both sexual and urinary function may be injured. Dissection at the sacral promontory may injure the hypogastric nerves (sympathetic) if care is not taken to isolate them. Although urinary retention should be expected in the postoperative period, disruption to the bladder's autonomic supply may result in bladder dystonia, which may resolve over months or be permanent. In men, sexual dysfunction manifests as an inability to achieve an erection, a half erection, or retrograde ejaculation. 

Other options:

Option A: A high anterior resection refers to the surgical removal of the distal sigmoid colon and upper rectum. This procedure is commonly performed to treat benign conditions and diseases located at the rectosigmoid junction, such as diverticulitis.

Option B: Hartman's operation is indicated in elderly and frail patients who have poor anal sphincter function or postoperative incontinence. In this surgery, colorectal excision is done along with the closure of the rectal stump and permanent proximal colostomy.

Option D: Endoluminal stent is indicated in patients with obstructive rectal carcinoma and also as a palliative procedure. Only rectosigmoid and upper rectal tumors are suitable for stenting because, in low cancers, stent impingement results in tenesmus.

questions.text: A multigravida who is a known case of diabetes delivers a newborn of weight 4.5 kg as shown in the image below. Which of the following complications can be seen in the neonate?
questions.solution:
Small left colon syndrome is one of the complications which can be seen in this neonate. 

The birth weight of 4.5 kg and the image provided indicates that the baby is macrosomia (large for gestational age).

In pregestational diabetes and gestational diabetes mellitus, maternal hyperglycemia causes a higher amount of blood glucose to pass through the placenta into the fetal circulation. It results in fetal hyperglycemia leading to fetal hyperinsulinism. As a result, extra glucose in the fetus is stored as body fat causing macrosomia. These newborns are at risk of developing various complications due to fetal hyperglycemia. They are:

  • Gastrointestinal: These infants may demonstrate abdominal distention caused by a transient delay in the development of the left side of the colon due to fluctuations in maternal and fetal glucose resulting in small left colon syndrome.
  • Metabolic: Hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia
  • Neural: Neural tube defects like caudal regression syndrome, encephalocele, anencephaly 
  • Respiratory: Respiratory distress syndrome, transient tachypnea of newborn, persistent pulmonary hypertension
  • Cardiac: Cardiomegaly, cardiac malformations like a ventricular or atrial septal defect, transposition of the great vessels, truncus arteriosus, double-outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, coarctation of the aorta
  • Hematological: Polycythemia, renal vein thrombosis
  • Others: Hyperbilirubinemia, insulin resistance, diabetes, sudden intrauterine death

Other options:

Option B- Hypermagnesemia is not seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Hypomagnesemia is seen due to the perinatal asphyxia.

Option C- Hyperglycemia is seen in the fetus and not in the neonate. Neonates present with hypoglycemia due to increased insulin.

Option D- Umbilical hernia is seen in congenital hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 16-year-old woman was brought by her parents with sudden onset of blindness in both eyes. On examination, fundoscopy and cortical-evoked potentials were normal. On further probing the history, there were frequent fights between her parents, and the onset of blindness corresponded to one of their fights. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Receiving support from others constitutes secondary gain
It is caused due to repression of conflicts in the unconscious mind
Patient is unconcerned about severe symptoms

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of conversion disorder. There is no organic neurological lesion present in such patients. The symptoms displayed cannot be explained by any neurological disease.

Conversion disorder is an acute and temporary loss or alteration in motor or sensory function triggered by psychosocial conflict. The patients tend to keep the psychological impact of the stressors in life repressed in their unconscious mind (option B). This stress is converted into physical symptoms such as non-epileptic seizures, paralysis, or blindness.

The patient's symptoms do not fit into the diagnosis of any neurological disorder and they cannot be explained by any neurological lesion — this is known as astasia abasia. The patients are unconcerned about even severe symptoms such as blindness (option C) — this is known as la belle indifference.

Patients achieve primary gain by keeping internal conflicts outside their awareness and then releasing them as physical symptoms. When the patients get advantages due to their symptoms, such as attention and care from the family, it is known as secondary gain (option A).

questions.text: A carpenter presented with irritation and blurring of vision in both his eyes for 1 week. He gives a history of a wood chip penetrating into his right eye 3 weeks back. On evaluation, the visual acuity of the left eye was 6/12, while that of the right eye was light perception. Fundoscopic examination revealed Dalen-Fuchs nodules. Which of the following is the best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sympathetic ophthalmitis. The best step in the management of this patient is the enucleation of the right eye.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. Both the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye) develop panuveitis. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.

It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are granulomas located between the Bruch membrane and retinal pigmented epithelium; they are seen in Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome and sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are shown in the image below.

The exciting eye shows features of low-grade uveitis such as ciliary congestion, lacrimation, and tenderness. The sympathizing eye is usually involved 4-8 weeks later. It has a prodromal stage with photophobia, ciliary congestion, and keratic precipitates. In the fully developed stage, symptoms of acute iridocyclitis supervene.

Steroids remain the basis of treatment. High-dose prednisolone or intravenous methylprednisolone is given to reduce inflammation. Enucleation of the exciting eye should be done when the exciting eye has a poor visual prognosis. Enucleation of the exciting eye is considered effective in preventing or reducing the severity of sympathetic ophthalmitis. Immunosuppressants like azathioprine, ciclosporin, and methotrexate can be given in resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.

Other options:

Option A: In this case, the left eye will be the sympathizing eye and the right eye will be the exciting eye as there is a history of penetrating trauma to the right eye. Enucleation should be considered in the exciting eye with a poor visual prognosis. Therefore, enucleation of the left eye is not the answer.

Option C: Sympathetic ophthalmitis does not undergo spontaneous resolution as the exciting eye induces the inflammation unless treated with steroids or enucleated. So, treatment should be either with steroids prophylactically or enucleation of the exciting eye if there is poor visual prognosis.

Option D: Oral cyclosporine is indicated in resistant sympathetic ophthalmitis or as a steroid-sparing agent.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain. He states that he has been having 4-5 non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. He denies any family history of colon cancer. A biopsy of the small bowel showed findings as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most commonly associated cancer?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with the biopsy image showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and lamina propria infiltrates, indicates a case of celiac disease. The most common celiac disease-associated cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

Celiac disease/celiac sprue/gluten-sensitive enteropathy:

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy. It is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8. The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin (gluten-derived peptide). The gliadin peptide activates the epithelial cells to express IL-15, which in turn triggers activation and proliferation of CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes. This damages the epithelium and increases the passage of gliadin into the lamina propria, where gliadin is deamidated by the tissue transglutaminase (tTG), an intestinal enzyme. The deamidated gliadin is more immunogenic and is presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation and worsen tissue damage.

Microscopic findings on biopsy of the proximal small intestine will show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes.

Clinically, patients with celiac disease present with malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, chronic refractory anemia, and marked unintentional weight loss. Some patients may also present with dermatitis herpetiformis characterized by herpes-like vesicles that are caused due to the deposition of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae.

Antiendomysial and anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are found in serological studies. Symptoms can be reversed by a gluten-free diet.

In refractory cases of celiac disease, patients should be started on oral steroids (prednisolone). After induction of clinical remission, azathioprine can be added.

The below image shows a patient with dermatitis herpetiformis.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

The following are the general tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Fat malabsorption

Qualitative: Sudan III staining

C14 Triolein breath test

Fecal steatocrit
Carbohydrate malabsorption

D-xylose test

Lactose hydrogen breath test
Protein malabsorption C13 egg-white breath test

The following are the specific tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Celiac disease

Anti-tissue transglutaminase (anti-tTG)

Anti-endomysial antibodies

Mucosal biopsy showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, lamina propria infiltrates, and normal mucosal thickness.
Whipple's disease Mucosal biopsy showing PAS +ve macrophages in lamina propria
Pancreatic insufficiency

Fecal elastase

Fecal chymotrypsin
Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)

Due to Enterobacter or Pseudomonas - jejunal aspirate >103 CFU

Due to other organisms - jejunal aspirate >105 CFU

Related Pearl: Lymphomas with Etiology

questions.text: A 40-year-year old woman presented with vegetations as shown in the image. On histopathology, a suprabasal cleft with acantholysis is seen. On immunofluorescence, intraepidermal intercellular IgG and C3 deposits are seen. Which of the following histopathological finding can be seen with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pemphigus vegetans because of the development of vegetations in the flexural areas, intraepidermal cleft and intercellular IgG and C3 deposits. Intraepidermal eosinophilic microabscess is the histopathological finding seen in this condition. 

Pemphigus vegetans is a rare variant of pemphigus vulgaris. It is characterized by vegetating erosions primarily in the flexures. It has circulating antibodies primarily against desmoglein 3, as in pemphigus vulgaris and in some cases against desmocollin. It has 2 subtypes namely Neumann type which is severe and Hallopeau type which is mild.

It is seen more commonly in middle-aged adults. The vegetating lesions are primarily in flexural areas which are hyperkeratotic, papillomatous and acanthotic.

On histopathology, the findings include hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, acantholysis with a suprabasal cleft, eosinophilic spongiosis, intraepidermal eosinophilic microabscess and eosinophilic dermal infiltrate. Direct immunofluorescence is similar to pemphigus vulgaris that show intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3.

The below image shows the fishnet pattern of pemphigus vegetans on direct immunofluorescence similar to pemphigus vulgaris.

The below image shows lesions seen in pemphigus vegetans.

A microabscess is a small cavity in the epidermis or dermis formed by collections of leucocytes.

Some types of microabscesses and their examples are given below:

Predominant cell

Name of microabscess

Disease
Neutrophilic microabscess
  • Papillary tip microabscess

 

  • Munroe's microabscess (superficial)

 

  • Spongiform pustules of Kogoj (deep)
  • Dermatitis Herpetiformis

 

  • Psoriasis

 

  • Psoriasis
Lymphocytic microabscess Pautrier's microabscess Mycosis fungoides
Eosinophilic microabscess   Pemphigus vegetans

Other options:

Option A- Papillary tip neutrophilic microabscess is seen in dermatitis herpetiformis that is a subepidermal immunobullous disorder. On direct immunofluorescence, IgA deposition in the papillary dermis is seen.

Options B and C- Spongiform pustules of Kogoj are neutrophilic infiltrates in the Malpighian layer. Munro's microabscess is a neutrophilic microabscess present in the stratum corneum of the skin. These are seen in psoriasis.
